sub_topic_details.sub_topic_description: The Point-Slope Form is a method to write the equation of a line using a point on the line and the slope. The standard form is expressed as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mrow> <mi>y</mi> <mo>-</mo> <msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub> <mo>=</mo> <mi>m</mi> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>-</mo> <msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </math> where <bold>(x₁, y₁)</bold> is a point on the line and <bold>m</bold> is the slope of the line. This form is particularly useful when you know the slope and a point that the line passes through.

Concepts.Concept:
• (x, y) represents any point on the line
• (x₁, y₁) is a specific known point on the line • m is the slope of the line, calculated as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mrow> <mi>m</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow> <mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </math>

• The form emphasizes the relationship between any point (x, y) and a specific point (x₁, y₁)
• The equation shows how far any point is from the known point, both horizontally (x - x₁) and vertically (y - y₁) • The slope m determines the rate of change between these points

To convert from point-slope to slope-intercept form:
Distribute m: <bold>y - y₁ = mx - mx₁</bold> Add y₁ to both sides: <bold>y = mx - mx₁ + y₁</bold> Combine like terms to get: <bold>y = mx + b</bold> where <bold>b = -mx₁ + y₁</bold>

• Finding equations of lines when given a point and slope
• Writing equations of parallel or perpendicular lines through a point • Modeling real-world situations where rate of change (slope) and initial conditions (point) are known

• Forgetting to subtract x₁ and y₁ in the formula
• Mixing up the order of subtraction in (x - x₁) or (y - y₁) • Using the wrong point coordinates when multiple points are given • Not distributing the slope m properly when expanding the equation
